trans-unit.source: Use PowerShell to manage Service Bus and Event Hubs resources
trans-unit.target: Use PowerShell to manage Service Bus and Event Hubs resources

trans-unit.source: Using PowerShell to create and manage Service Bus and Event Hubs resources
trans-unit.target: Using PowerShell to create and manage Service Bus and Event Hubs resources

trans-unit.source: Use PowerShell to manage Service Bus and Event Hubs resources
trans-unit.target: Use PowerShell to manage Service Bus and Event Hubs resources

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure PowerShell is a scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of Azure services.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure PowerShell is a scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of Azure services.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to use PowerShell to provision and manage Service Bus entities such as namespaces, queues, and Event Hubs using a local Azure PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to use PowerShell to provision and manage Service Bus entities such as namespaces, queues, and Event Hubs using a local Azure PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you begin, you'll need the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin, you'll need the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Azure is a subscription-based platform.
trans-unit.target: Azure is a subscription-based platform.

trans-unit.source: For more
trans-unit.target: For more

trans-unit.source: information about obtaining a subscription, see [Purchase Options], [Member Offers], or [Free Trial].
trans-unit.target: information about obtaining a subscription, see [Purchase Options], [Member Offers], or [Free Trial].

trans-unit.source: A computer with Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: A computer with Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see [Install and configure Azure PowerShell]
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see [Install and configure Azure PowerShell]

trans-unit.source: A general understanding of PowerShell scripts, NuGet packages, and the .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: A general understanding of PowerShell scripts, NuGet packages, and the .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: Include a reference to the .NET assembly for Service Bus
trans-unit.target: Include a reference to the .NET assembly for Service Bus

trans-unit.source: There are a limited number of PowerShell cmdlets available for managing Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: There are a limited number of PowerShell cmdlets available for managing Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: To provision entities that are not exposed through the existing cmdlets, you can use the .NET client for Service Bus from within PowerShell by referencing the [Service Bus NuGet package].
trans-unit.target: To provision entities that are not exposed through the existing cmdlets, you can use the .NET client for Service Bus from within PowerShell by referencing the [Service Bus NuGet package].

trans-unit.source: First, make sure that the script can locate the **Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll** assembly, which is installed with the NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: First, make sure that the script can locate the **Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll** assembly, which is installed with the NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: In order to be flexible, the script performs these steps:
trans-unit.target: In order to be flexible, the script performs these steps:

trans-unit.source: Determines the path from which it was invoked.
trans-unit.target: Determines the path from which it was invoked.

trans-unit.source: Traverses the path until it finds a folder named `packages`.
trans-unit.target: Traverses the path until it finds a folder named `packages`.

trans-unit.source: This folder is created when you install NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: This folder is created when you install NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: Recursively searches the `packages` folder for an assembly named **Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll**.
trans-unit.target: Recursively searches the `packages` folder for an assembly named **Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll**.

trans-unit.source: References the assembly so that the types are available for later use.
trans-unit.target: References the assembly so that the types are available for later use.

trans-unit.source: Here's how these steps are implemented in a PowerShell script:
trans-unit.target: Here's how these steps are implemented in a PowerShell script:

trans-unit.source: Provision a Service Bus namespace
trans-unit.target: Provision a Service Bus namespace

trans-unit.source: When working with Service Bus namespaces, there are two cmdlets you can use instead of the .NET SDK: [Get-AzureSBNamespace] and [New-AzureSBNamespace].
trans-unit.target: When working with Service Bus namespaces, there are two cmdlets you can use instead of the .NET SDK: [Get-AzureSBNamespace] and [New-AzureSBNamespace].

trans-unit.source: This example creates a few local variables in the script; `$Namespace` and `$Location`.
trans-unit.target: This example creates a few local variables in the script; `$Namespace` and `$Location`.

trans-unit.source: `$Namespace` is the name the of the Service Bus namespace with which we want to work.
trans-unit.target: `$Namespace` is the name the of the Service Bus namespace with which we want to work.

trans-unit.source: `$Location` identifies the data center in which will we provision the namespace.
trans-unit.target: `$Location` identifies the data center in which will we provision the namespace.

trans-unit.source: `$CurrentNamespace` stores the reference namespace that we retrieve (or create).
trans-unit.target: `$CurrentNamespace` stores the reference namespace that we retrieve (or create).

trans-unit.source: In an actual script, `$Namespace` and `$Location` can be passed as parameters.
trans-unit.target: In an actual script, `$Namespace` and `$Location` can be passed as parameters.

trans-unit.source: This part of the script does the following:
trans-unit.target: This part of the script does the following:

trans-unit.source: Attempts to retrieve a Service Bus namespace with the provided name.
trans-unit.target: Attempts to retrieve a Service Bus namespace with the provided name.

trans-unit.source: If the namespace is found, it reports what was found.
trans-unit.target: If the namespace is found, it reports what was found.

trans-unit.source: If the namespace is not found, it creates the namespace and then retrieves the newly created namespace.
trans-unit.target: If the namespace is not found, it creates the namespace and then retrieves the newly created namespace.

trans-unit.source: To provision other Service Bus entities, create an instance of the `NamespaceManager` object from the SDK.
trans-unit.target: To provision other Service Bus entities, create an instance of the `NamespaceManager` object from the SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can use the [Get-AzureSBAuthorizationRule] cmdlet to retrieve an authorization rule that's used to provide a connection string.
trans-unit.target: You can use the [Get-AzureSBAuthorizationRule] cmdlet to retrieve an authorization rule that's used to provide a connection string.

trans-unit.source: This example stores a reference to the `NamespaceManager` instance in the `$NamespaceManager` variable.
trans-unit.target: This example stores a reference to the `NamespaceManager` instance in the `$NamespaceManager` variable.

trans-unit.source: The script later uses `$NamespaceManager` to provision other entities.
trans-unit.target: The script later uses `$NamespaceManager` to provision other entities.

trans-unit.source: Provisioning other Service Bus entities
trans-unit.target: Provisioning other Service Bus entities

trans-unit.source: To provision other entities, such as queues, topics, and Event Hubs, you can use the [.NET API for Service Bus].
trans-unit.target: To provision other entities, such as queues, topics, and Event Hubs, you can use the [.NET API for Service Bus].

trans-unit.source: More detailed examples, including other entities, are referenced at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: More detailed examples, including other entities, are referenced at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: Create an Event Hub
trans-unit.target: Create an Event Hub

trans-unit.source: This part of the script creates four more local variables.
trans-unit.target: This part of the script creates four more local variables.

trans-unit.source: These variables are used to instantiate an `EventHubDescription` object.
trans-unit.target: These variables are used to instantiate an `EventHubDescription` object.

trans-unit.source: The script does the following:
trans-unit.target: The script does the following:

trans-unit.source: Using the `NamespaceManager` object, check to see if the Event Hub identified by `$Path` exists.
trans-unit.target: Using the `NamespaceManager` object, check to see if the Event Hub identified by `$Path` exists.

trans-unit.source: If it does not exist, create an `EventHubDescription` and pass that to the `NamespaceManager` class `CreateEventHubIfNotExists` method.
trans-unit.target: If it does not exist, create an `EventHubDescription` and pass that to the `NamespaceManager` class `CreateEventHubIfNotExists` method.

trans-unit.source: After determining that the Event Hub is available, create a consumer group using `ConsumerGroupDescription` and `NamespaceManager`.
trans-unit.target: After determining that the Event Hub is available, create a consumer group using `ConsumerGroupDescription` and `NamespaceManager`.

trans-unit.source: Create a queue
trans-unit.target: Create a queue

trans-unit.source: To create a queue or topic, perform a namespace check as in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: To create a queue or topic, perform a namespace check as in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: Create a topic
trans-unit.target: Create a topic

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This article provides you with a basic outline for provisioning Service Bus entities using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article provides you with a basic outline for provisioning Service Bus entities using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Although there are a limited number of PowerShell cmdlets available for managing Service Bus messaging entities, by referencing the Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll assembly, virtually any operation you can perform using the .NET client libraries you can also perform in a PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: Although there are a limited number of PowerShell cmdlets available for managing Service Bus messaging entities, by referencing the Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll assembly, virtually any operation you can perform using the .NET client libraries you can also perform in a PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: There are more detailed examples available on these blogs posts:
trans-unit.target: There are more detailed examples available on these blogs posts:

trans-unit.source: How to create Service Bus queues, topics and subscriptions using a PowerShell script
trans-unit.target: How to create Service Bus queues, topics and subscriptions using a PowerShell script

trans-unit.source: How to create a Service Bus Namespace and an Event Hub using a PowerShell script
trans-unit.target: How to create a Service Bus Namespace and an Event Hub using a PowerShell script

trans-unit.target: Some ready-made script are also available for download:

trans-unit.target: Service Bus PowerShell Scripts
